dict.string: Works in conjuction with Sticky Notifications (app).

set inputStr to "{query}" set my text item delimiters to ":" if number of text items of inputStr = 1 then set nMessage to last text item of inputStr set urlScheme to "sticky-notifications://note?message=" & nMessage end if if number of text items of inputStr = 2 then set nTitle to first text item of inputStr set nMessage to last text item of inputStr set urlScheme to "sticky-notifications://note?title=" & nTitle & "&message=" & nMessage end if if number of text items of inputStr = 3 then set nTitle to first text item of inputStr set nSubtitle to second text item of inputStr set nMessage to last text item of inputStr set urlScheme to "sticky-notifications://note?title=" & nTitle & "&subtitle= " & nSubtitle & "&message=" & nMessage end if tell application "System Events" open location urlScheme end tell

You will need to get Sticky Notifications from the app store for this workflow to work: https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/sticky-notifications/id552377168?mt=12
“Sticky Notifications” and yellow sticky icon © Instinctive Code - http://instinctivecode.com
